Participants.evidence: Twenty-three patients with subtrochanteric aseptic nonunions, aged under 60 years, and with 2.0 to 5.0 cm shortening were recruited.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either the intervention or standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the effectiveness of a novel surgical technique for these conditions.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the union rate, evaluated over a minimum follow-up of 1.2 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed with sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the intervention, blinding was not feasible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Twenty-three patients with subtrochanteric aseptic nonunions

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group achieved a 100% union rate (21/21) with a median union period of 4.0 months (range, 3.5–11 months).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
